Statistics for Novice Researchers: A Complete Guide

Source: STATISTICS_FOR_NOVICES.md

Welcome!

You donâ€™t need to be a statistician to do rigorous research. This guide explains every statistical concept in the consumeR package in plain English, with real examples.

Table of Contents

  1. Understanding P-Values
  2. What Are Effect Sizes?
  3. Understanding Assumptions
  4. Choosing the Right Test
  5. Reading Statistical Output

Understanding P-Values

What is a p-value?

Simple answer: The p-value tells you how likely your results are due to random chance.

Analogy: Imagine flipping a coin 100 times and getting 75 heads. That seems suspicious, right? The p-value tells you: â€œIf this were a fair coin, whatâ€™s the probability of getting 75 or more heads?â€ If that probability is very low (p < .05), youâ€™d conclude the coin is probably unfair.

The Magic Number: 0.05

  • p < 0.05: Your result is â€œstatistically significantâ€ âœ“
    • Less than 5% chance this happened by random luck
    • You can be reasonably confident thereâ€™s a real effect
  • p â‰¥ 0.05: Your result is â€œnot statistically significantâ€ âœ—
    • More than 5% chance this happened by random luck
    • You canâ€™t rule out that itâ€™s just noise

Common Misconceptions

âŒ WRONG: â€œp = .03 means thereâ€™s a 97% chance my hypothesis is trueâ€ âœ… RIGHT: â€œp = .03 means if there were NO effect, Iâ€™d only see results this extreme 3% of the timeâ€

âŒ WRONG: â€œp = .06 means my hypothesis is falseâ€ âœ… RIGHT: â€œp = .06 means I donâ€™t have enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis at the conventional .05 levelâ€

âŒ WRONG: â€œp = .001 means a bigger effect than p = .04â€ âœ… RIGHT: â€œBoth are significant, but effect SIZE (not p-value) tells you how big the difference isâ€

How consumeR Reports P-Values

result <- test_group_differences(group1, group2)
result$p_value
# 0.0234

result$significant
# TRUE (because 0.0234 < 0.05)

In your manuscript: > â€œGroups differed significantly (p = .023)â€ or â€œp < .05â€ if very small

What Are Effect Sizes?

The Problem with P-Values Alone

Scenario 1: You have 1,000,000 participants. Groups differ by 0.1 points on a 7-point scale. - P-value: p < .001 âœ“ Significant! - Practical importance: Basically zero. Who cares about 0.1 points?

Scenario 2: You have 20 participants. Groups differ by 2 points on a 7-point scale. - P-value: p = .08 âœ— Not significant - Practical importance: Could be huge! But you donâ€™t have enough data to prove it.

The lesson: P-values tell you if an effect EXISTS. Effect sizes tell you if it MATTERS.

Cohenâ€™s d (for t-tests)

What it means: How many standard deviations apart are the two group means?

Interpretation: - d = 0.2: Small effect (groups overlap a lot) - d = 0.5: Medium effect (noticeable difference) - d = 0.8: Large effect (groups clearly distinct)

Real-world analogy: - d = 0.2: Like comparing heights of 13-year-olds vs.Â 13.5-year-olds - d = 0.5: Like comparing heights of 13-year-olds vs.Â 15-year-olds - d = 0.8: Like comparing heights of 13-year-olds vs.Â 18-year-olds

consumeR output:

result$effect_size
# 0.65

result$effect_interpretation
# "medium"

In your manuscript: > â€œThe treatment group showed higher satisfaction than control (Cohenâ€™s d = 0.65, a medium effect size)â€

Eta-Squared (Î·Â²) for ANOVA

What it means: What percentage of variance is explained by your groups?

Interpretation: - Î·Â² = 0.01: Small effect (1% of variance explained) - Î·Â² = 0.06: Medium effect (6% of variance explained) - Î·Â² = 0.14: Large effect (14% of variance explained)

Real-world meaning: If Î·Â² = 0.10, that means 10% of the differences in your outcome variable are explained by which group people are in, and 90% is due to other factors (individual differences, measurement error, etc.).

RÂ² for Regression

What it means: How much of the variation in Y can be predicted from X?

Interpretation: - RÂ² = 0.10: Your predictors explain 10% of variance - RÂ² = 0.30: Your predictors explain 30% of variance (pretty good!) - RÂ² = 0.50: Your predictors explain 50% of variance (excellent!)

Example: If youâ€™re predicting customer satisfaction (Y) from price, quality, and service (X), and RÂ² = 0.40, that means these three factors explain 40% of why some customers are more satisfied than others.

Understanding Assumptions

What Are Assumptions?

Statistical tests make assumptions - like rules that need to be (mostly) true for the test to work correctly.

Analogy: A recipe assumes you have an oven. If you donâ€™t have an oven, you need a different recipe. Same with stats - if assumptions arenâ€™t met, you need a different test.

The Big Three Assumptions

1. Independence

What it means: Each observation should be independent - knowing one personâ€™s score shouldnâ€™t tell you about another personâ€™s score.

Violated when: - âœ— You measure the same person multiple times (use repeated measures tests) - âœ— You have nested data (students within classrooms - use multilevel models) - âœ— You have matched pairs (siblings, couples - use paired tests)

How consumeR checks this: We canâ€™t test this statistically - itâ€™s about your research design. We ask YOU to think about whether observations are independent.

2. Normality

What it means: Your data should follow a bell-shaped curve (normal distribution).

Why it matters: Many tests assume data is normally distributed. If itâ€™s not, the test might give you wrong answers.

How to tell:

# consumeR checks this automatically
result <- test_group_differences(group1, group2)
result$assumptions$normality_group1

# Results:
# "The normality assumption is MET"  âœ“
# or
# "The normality assumption is VIOLATED"  âœ—

What to do if violated: 1. Use non-parametric tests (Wilcoxon instead of t-test) - consumeR does this automatically! 2. Transform your data (log, square root) 3. If n > 30, often okay anyway (Central Limit Theorem)

Visual check: - Make a histogram - does it look roughly bell-shaped? - Make a Q-Q plot - do points fall roughly on a line?

3. Homogeneity of Variance

What it means: Groups should have similar â€œspreadâ€ (variability).

Example: - Group A: scores range from 5-7 (very consistent) - Group B: scores range from 1-10 (all over the place) - Problem! The spreads are very different.

How consumeR checks:

result$assumptions$homogeneity

# "The homogeneity of variance assumption is MET"  âœ“
# or
# "The homogeneity of variance assumption is VIOLATED"  âœ—

What to do if violated: - Use Welchâ€™s t-test instead of Studentâ€™s t-test - consumeR automatically does this for you!

Choosing the Right Test

Decision Tree

Start here: Whatâ€™s your research question?

Comparing Two Groups

Question: â€œAre two groups different?â€ Examples: - Treatment vs.Â Control - Before vs.Â After - Men vs.Â Women

Test: test_group_differences()

result <- test_group_differences(
  data$outcome[data$group == "Treatment"],
  data$outcome[data$group == "Control"]
)

What it does: - Checks if assumptions are met - Automatically picks the right test (t-test or Wilcoxon) - Gives you publication-ready output

Comparing Three or More Groups

Question: â€œDo multiple groups differ?â€ Examples: - Low vs.Â Medium vs.Â High price - Four different marketing messages - Three market segments

Test: compare_groups_anova()

result <- compare_groups_anova(
  data,
  formula = satisfaction ~ segment
)

What it does: - Checks if ANY groups differ (F-test) - If yes, tells you WHICH groups differ (post-hoc tests) - Handles unequal variances (Welchâ€™s ANOVA)

Predicting an Outcome

Question: â€œWhat predicts my outcome?â€ Examples: - Do price, quality, and service predict satisfaction? - Does ad spending predict sales?

Test: analyze_regression()

result <- analyze_regression(
  data,
  satisfaction ~ price + quality + service
)

What it does: - Tells you which predictors matter - Shows how much variance is explained (RÂ²) - Checks all regression assumptions

Measuring Relationships

Question: â€œAre two variables related?â€ Examples: - Is satisfaction correlated with loyalty? - Do price and quality go together?

Test: analyze_correlation()

result <- analyze_correlation(
  data,
  "satisfaction",
  "loyalty"
)

What it does: - Measures strength of relationship (r) - Picks Pearson or Spearman based on normality - Tells you if itâ€™s significant

Reading Statistical Output

Example: T-Test Output

result <- test_group_differences(treatment, control)
print(result)

What youâ€™ll see:

â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
GROUP COMPARISON RESULTS
â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

Test Used: Student's t-test
Sample Sizes: Group 1 (n = 50), Group 2 (n = 50)

DESCRIPTIVE STATISTICS:
  Group 1: M = 7.45, SD = 1.23
  Group 2: M = 6.12, SD = 1.45
  Difference: 1.33, 95% CI [0.78, 1.88]

STATISTICAL RESULTS:
  Test statistic: 4.523
  Degrees of freedom: 98
  p-value: < .001
  Significant: YES (p < .05)

EFFECT SIZE:
  Cohen's d = 0.98 (large)

INTERPRETATION:
  The groups are significantly different (p < .001).
  Group 1 (M = 7.45, SD = 1.23) has a higher mean than
  Group 2 (M = 6.12, SD = 1.45), with a mean difference
  of 1.33. The effect size is large (Cohen's d = 0.98).

How to read this:

  1. Test Used - Which test was run (t-test, Wilcoxon, etc.)
  2. Sample Sizes - How many people in each group
  3. Descriptive Statistics:
    • M = Mean (average)
    • SD = Standard Deviation (how spread out scores are)
    • 95% CI = Confidence Interval (range where true difference likely falls)
  4. Statistical Results:
    • Test statistic - Technical number (ignore unless asked)
    • p-value - Is it significant? (look for < .05)
  5. Effect Size - How big is the difference? (small/medium/large)
  6. Interpretation - Plain English summary

What to Report in Your Manuscript

Minimal reporting: > â€œTreatment group (M = 7.45, SD = 1.23) scored higher than control group (M = 6.12, SD = 1.45), t(98) = 4.52, p < .001, d = 0.98.â€

With publication text:

print(result, show_publication = TRUE)
# Copy-paste the output into your manuscript!

Common Mistakes to Avoid

1. P-Hacking

What it is: Running many tests until you find p < .05

Example of p-hacking:

# DON'T DO THIS:
test_group_differences(satisfaction, condition)  # p = .08 (not sig)
test_group_differences(satisfaction, age_group)  # p = .12 (not sig)
test_group_differences(satisfaction, gender)     # p = .03 (sig!) â† Report this one

Why itâ€™s bad: If you run 20 tests, youâ€™ll get 1 significant result by chance (5% = 1 in 20)

How to avoid: - Pre-register your hypotheses - Only test what you said youâ€™d test - Report ALL tests you ran, not just significant ones

2. Ignoring Effect Sizes

The mistake: > â€œWe found a significant difference (p < .001)â€

Better: > â€œWe found a significant difference (p < .001, d = 0.25)â€

Why it matters: With huge samples, tiny meaningless differences can be â€œsignificantâ€

3. Assuming p > .05 Means â€œNo Effectâ€

The mistake: > â€œThere was no effect (p = .08)â€

Better: > â€œThere was no statistically significant effect (p = .08), though the effect size was small to medium (d = 0.35). The study may have been underpowered.â€

Why: Absence of evidence â‰  evidence of absence

4. Not Checking Assumptions

The mistake:

# Just run the test without checking anything
t.test(group1, group2)

Better:

# Let consumeR check assumptions for you
result <- test_group_differences(group1, group2)
print(result, show_assumptions = TRUE)

Why: If assumptions are violated, your p-values might be wrong

5. Confusing Correlation with Causation

The mistake: > â€œIce cream sales cause drowning deaths (r = .95, p < .001)â€

Reality: - Both increase in summer (confounding variable: temperature) - Correlation â‰  causation

Remember: - Correlation tells you variables go together - Only experiments (with random assignment) can show causation

Glossary

Alpha (Î±): The significance threshold, usually 0.05

ANOVA: Analysis of Variance - comparing 3+ groups

Assumptions: Requirements that must be (mostly) met for a test to work properly

Central Limit Theorem: With large samples (n > 30), means are normally distributed even if raw data isnâ€™t

Cohenâ€™s d: Effect size for t-tests (standardized mean difference)

Confidence Interval (CI): Range where the true value probably falls (usually 95% CI)

Correlation (r): Measures strength of relationship (-1 to +1)

Degrees of Freedom (df): Technical parameter related to sample size

Effect Size: How big/important an effect is (not just if itâ€™s significant)

Eta-squared (Î·Â²): Effect size for ANOVA (proportion of variance explained)

Homogeneity of Variance: Groups have similar spread/variability

Hypothesis: - Null hypothesis: Thereâ€™s no effect - Alternative hypothesis: There is an effect

Independence: Each observation is unrelated to others

Normality: Data follows a bell-shaped curve

Non-parametric Test: Test that doesnâ€™t assume normality (e.g., Wilcoxon)

P-value: Probability of getting results this extreme if null hypothesis is true

Post-hoc Test: Follow-up tests after ANOVA to see which groups differ

Power: Ability to detect an effect if one exists (higher is better)

RÂ² (R-squared): Proportion of variance explained by predictors (regression)

Regression: Predicting an outcome from one or more predictors

Residuals: Differences between observed and predicted values

Standard Deviation (SD): Average distance from the mean (measure of spread)

Standard Error (SE): Uncertainty in an estimate (smaller is better)

Statistical Significance: p < .05 (conventionally)

Test Statistic: Technical value from test (t, F, r, etc.)

T-test: Comparing means of two groups

Type I Error: False positive (saying thereâ€™s an effect when there isnâ€™t)

Type II Error: False negative (missing an effect thatâ€™s really there)

Welchâ€™s Test: Version of t-test/ANOVA that doesnâ€™t assume equal variances

Wilcoxon Test: Non-parametric version of t-test

Quick Reference Card

When to Use Each Test

Research Question Test consumeR Function
Compare 2 groups t-test test_group_differences()
Compare 3+ groups ANOVA compare_groups_anova()
Predict outcome Regression analyze_regression()
Measure relationship Correlation analyze_correlation()

Interpreting Effect Sizes

Effect Size Cohenâ€™s d Î·Â² RÂ²
Small 0.2 0.01 0.10
Medium 0.5 0.06 0.30
Large 0.8 0.14 0.50

P-Value Guide

P-value Meaning Symbol
< .001 Very strong evidence ***
< .01 Strong evidence **
< .05 Significant *
< .10 Marginal .
â‰¥ .10 Not significant ns

Getting Help

Still confused? Thatâ€™s normal! Statistics is hard.

Resources: 1. Read the verbose output: print(result, show_assumptions = TRUE) 2. Check the guide: ?test_group_differences 3. Look at examples: All functions have working examples 4. Ask for help: Statistics consultants, your advisor, online forums

Remember: You donâ€™t need to understand every detail. The consumeR package does the technical stuff. You just need to: 1. Know which test answers your question 2. Understand the output 3. Report it correctly in your paper

The package gives you MORE explanation than you need - choose what makes sense for your level and your journalâ€™s requirements.

Good luck with your research! ğŸ‰
